Risk Management Plan for PSNH Merrimack Station 

EPA ID # 1000 0007 9309



Northeast Utilities Environmental Management System



As a leading regional provider of energy products and services, Northeast Utilities is committed to operating an effective Environmental Management System (EMS) as part of an integrated framework for sustainable environmental stewardship.  Our EMS will comply with all applicable environmental statutes and regulations.   The EMS will be integrated with our mission to deliver excellence in safety service and value.  



To satisfy our commitment we will:

- Ensure compliance with all applicable environmental laws, regulations, and other requirements;

- Evaluate our work practices for environmental impacts and develop mitigation strategies to lessen impacts;

- Demonstrate improvement to our environmental performance in terms of both regulated and unregulated environmental impacts

- Employ source reduction, waste minimization and other pollution prevention approaches whenever practicable; and, 

- Ensure that our commitment to environmental excellence is communicated through all levels of the organization. 



Northeast Utilities expects all employees to understand and comply with the commitments outlined in the EMS and will promote the tenants of the EMS with our suppliers, vendors and contractors.



Management is responsible for implementation and oversight of the Environmental Management System. The Executive Environmental, Health and Safety Committee is responsible for oversight of the EMS.

 

A. ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

 

Northeast Utilities is committed to providing a safe and healthful working environment for all employees.  Achievement of this objective requires that all employees at all levels in the organization create and maintain safe and healthful working conditions.  This means strict adherence to established safety rules and practices, and the elimination of all unsafe acts from the

workplace.  Each employee, as a condition of employment, is accountable for adhering to safety rules and safe work practices.  The Executive Environmental, Health and Safety Committee is responsible for implementation of this policy.



Merrimack Station has incorporated the program elements from the OSHA Process Safety Management Regulation 29CFR 1910.119 into the routine operation of our facility as the foundation of an accidental release prevention program.  The station maintains an Emergency Response Plan that will be activated in the event of an emergency involving a regulated substance.  Merrimack Station is included in the local emergency response plan and our ERP is reviewed with the Bow Fire Department.



B. THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES HANDLED

 

Merrimack Station is a fossil fueled electric power generating facility owned and operated by Public Service of New Hampshire, a wholly owned subsidiary of Northeast Utilities of Berlin, CT.



The purpose of this facility is to generate electric power for sale via transmission and distribution lines to customers.  There are four separate units with a net claimed capacity of 478 megawatts.  Units 1 & 2 use coal fired cyclone boilers to produce steam that powers turbine driven generators capable of 108 and 330 megawatts respectively.  Oxides of nitrogen (NOx) form during the combustion process.



Selective Catalytic Reduction deNOx Technology (SCR) was installed in 1995 on Unit 2 and in 1999 on Unit 1 to remove emissions of nitrogen oxide (NOx) as part of the PSNH plan to comply with the 1990 Clean Air Act Amendments.  The application of SCR reduces NOx air emissions from the station in excess of 80%.  Ammonia, a regulated substance, is the reagent used in the process.  Ammonia vapor is added to the flue gas ahead of the catalyst bed where it combines with the NOx to form nitrogen gas and water vapor.



C. THE GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND THE SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS.

The ammonia storage and handling facility complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all applicable state codes and regulations.  The ammonia systems were designed and constructed with ANSI K61.1 Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia guidance.  The storage tanks are built to the ASME Pressure Vessel Code for Unfired Vessels.



Our accident prevention program is based on the OSHA Process Safety Management Plan which is a 13 point program for preventing or minimizing the consequences of catastrophic releases.  The Plan includes: routine maintenance and inspections, operating procedures, employee training in the hazards and handling of ammonia, and provides for periodic program audits.

 

All employees who operate ammonia equipment are trained in the hazards of ammonia.  Shift operators conduct rounds that include observations of the ammonia systems.  The storage and unloading facility is inspected weekly.  Trouble reports are submitted when action is required and qualified mechanics are on site to make repairs.  Pressure vessels are inspected according to the ASME.  A management of change process is followed for qualifying modifications to the covered processes.



D. FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

 

Merrimack Station went into commercial operation in 1960.  The first use of anhydrous ammonia on site was in 1991.  There have been no reportable releases of ammonia or related impacts from the use of ammonia to the health and safety of employees or the surrounding community.



E. THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM

 

A written Emergency Response Plan (ERP) or Integrated Contingency Plan provides guidance to employees in the event of any emergency at the station.  The primary contact during any emergency is the on-duty shift supervisor who is available on site 24/7.  There are 5 shift supervisors who work on rotating shifts.  Since the RMP only allows space for one contact person, the Station Manager was listed.  The ER

P includes procedures for notifying the local response agencies as required under the Emergency Planning and Community Right to Know Act (EPCRA).  The plan is submitted to and periodically reviewed with the Bow Fire Department (BFD) as the representative of the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  The BFD participates in the Capital Area Fire Mutual Aid Compact.  The BFD and the Central NH Hazmat Team are consulted in planning and conducting emergency response drills.

 

Access to the site is restricted to employees and authorized contractors.  Early warning systems include ammonia gas detectors that are strategically placed around the equipment.  Emergency response equipment is available on site. 



F. PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY 



Northeast Utilities and Merrimack Station are committed to providing a safe work environment.  The following items will be initiated as part of the ongoing program to ensure safety:



- Continue to provide annual refresher training to Hazardous Waste Operator/ Emergency Response Technicians to maintain their status at the 24 hour technician level.

- Review and update current contractor training program. 

- Perform non-destructive examination (NDE) on the ammonia storage tanks following a regular schedule.

- Replace hydrostatic relief valves with large valve considered to be more reliable. 

- Implement the recommendations from the Process Safety Management Audit conducted in November 2013 and the Process Hazard Analysis Revalidation conducted in May 2014.
